revision.text: {{talkheader}} {{ArticleHistory |action1=GAN |action1date=10:36, 17 August 2009 |action1link=Talk:Mackensen class battlecruiser/GA1 |action1result=listed |action1oldid=308368385 |maindate= 5 November 2015 |action2=FTC |action2date=16:07, 15 March 2010 |action2link=Wikipedia:Featured topic candidates/Battlecruisers of Germany/archive1 |action2result=promoted |action2oldid=346165371 |action3=FTC |action3date=22:33, 31 October 2013 (UTC) |action3link=Wikipedia:Featured topic candidates/Battlecruisers of the World/archive1 |action3result=promoted |action4=WAR |action4date=21:27, 19 April 2014 (UTC) |action4link=Wikipedia:WikiProject Military history/Assessment/Mackensen-class battlecruiser |action4result=approved |action4oldid=604604487 |ftname=Battlecruisers of the world |ft2name=Battlecruisers of Germany |currentstatus=FA |topic=War |dykdate=3 August 2009 |dykentry=... that the four '''{{sclass|Mackensen|battlecruiser|6}}s''' were canceled according to the terms of the [[Treaty of Versailles]] in 1919? |action5=FAC |action5date=2015-01-14 |action5link=Wikipedia:Featured article candidates/Mackensen-class battlecruiser/archive1 |action5result=promoted |action5oldid=642245363 }} {{WikiProjectBannerShell|1= {{MILHIST|class = FA|Maritime=yes|German=yes|OMT=1|A-Class = pass}} {{WikiProject Ships|class = FA}} {{WikiProject Germany|class = FA|importance=low}} }} == Accuracy of the horsepower figure == I do not know what the correct horsepower is. However the number shown (85,000) is too low. The Farragut class destroyer leaders (DLG-6) of the US Navy produced 87,000 in a ship of only 5,800 tons for 32 knots. The battle cruiser would require far more than that. [[User:KDTravis|KevinInMfrg]] ([[User talk:KDTravis|talk]]) 21:44, 17 June 2009 (UTC) :I've got a copy of Groner's ''German Warships 1815-1945'', I'll check it later tonight. It's probably correct though; {{SMS|Seydlitz}} had 63,000 shaft horsepower, for comparison. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] ([[User talk:Parsecboy|talk]]) 22:12, 17 June 2009 (UTC) ::Sorry it took me so long to reply here. Groner's does indeed give the figures as 90,000 shaft horsepower. The thing is, there were 4 shafts, so 90,000 on each shaft is quite a lot of horses. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] ([[User talk:Parsecboy|talk]]) 12:02, 28 July 2009 (UTC) ::Also, you require exponential increases in horsepower to achieve quite small increases in speed. The Iowas needed twice the horsepower of the South Dakotas (and a much finer hull) in order to realise a five knot increase in speed. 85,000 shp is about right for 28 knots in a 30,000 ton, four shaft ship. [[User:Getztashida|Getztashida]] ([[User talk:Getztashida|talk]]) 18:10, 20 January 2011 (UTC) == Secondary Armament == The article states that the Mackensen class ships had a secondary battery of twelve 15 cm guns however the accompanying illustration clearly shows that there are seven 15 cm guns mounted along the starboard side. Since there would have been an equal number of secondary guns on the opposite side it would appear that these ships actually mounted a secondary armament of fourteen guns. — Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/108.26.84.169|108.26.84.169]] ([[User talk:108.26.84.169|talk]]) 11:57, 28 April 2013 (UTC) :It's just a typo in the infobox - the text has the correct number. Thanks for pointing it out. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] ([[User talk:Parsecboy|talk]]) 17:33, 28 April 2013 (UTC) == New vector scetch with the latest changes in project (from Commons) == [[File:Mackensen class battlecruisers scetch.svg|600px|thumbnail|center]] Created for Russian good article. Based on original scetch printed in: *Gröner, Erich. Die deutschen Kriegsschiffe 1815-1945 Band 1: Panzerschiffe, Linienschiffe, Schlachschiffe, Flugzeugträger, Kreuzer, Kanonenboote. — Bernard & Graefe Verlag, 1982. — 180 p. — ISBN 978-3763748006 (main) *Breyer, Siegfried. Battleships of the world, 1905-1970. — Mayflower Books, 1980. — P. 400. — ISBN 978-0831707054 (boat) *Gerhard Koop, Klaus-Peter Schmolke Die Großen Kreuzer Von der Tann bis Hindenburg. — Bernard & Graefe, 1997. — 190 s. — ISBN 978-3763759729 (last changes in project) --[[User:Maxrossomachin|Maxrossomachin]] ([[User talk:Maxrossomachin|talk]]) 05:43, 29 April 2013 (UTC) :That looks great, thanks for posting this here. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] ([[User talk:Parsecboy|talk]]) 17:43, 29 April 2013 (UTC) ==FAC link broken== And I really don't see how... '''[[User:Adam Cuerden|Adam Cuerden]]''' ([[User talk:Adam Cuerden|talk]]) 21:01, 23 January 2015 (UTC) :Somehow when the article history was updated, the DYK line got spliced. Should be good now. Thanks for catching this Adam. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] ([[User talk:Parsecboy|talk]]) 21:23, 23 January 2015 (UTC) ::Was setting up the ''Signpost'' Featured content report. Makes it pretty obvious when your method of doing so is "open all articles in the weekly list, click to talk page of each, go back to start, click to FAC to get needed information." (That's simplified slightly - I also check for good images and such. MUST be something good. Give me the dates of major engagements. I'll check that book I have. I mean, I know it has Scharnhorst. '''[[User:Adam Cuerden|Adam Cuerden]]''' ([[User talk:Adam Cuerden|talk]]) 01:35, 24 January 2015 (UTC) == Fluid drive == Under "Machinery" we've got this: "The turbines mounted in Fürst Bismarck were equipped with Föttinger fluid transmission, while those on the other three ships were two sets of direct-coupled turbines with geared transmissions." Then this: "The ships' turbines were equipped with Föttinger gears..." Assuming "Föttinger gears" means fluid drive, these seem contradictory. [[User:Kendall-K1|Kendall-K1]] ([[User talk:Kendall-K1|talk]]) 12:56, 5 November 2015 (UTC) :I'll have a look at Hildebrand et. al. later today and get some clarification. Thanks for pointing it out. [[User:Parsecboy|Parsecboy]] ([[User talk:Parsecboy|talk]]) 13:00, 5 November 2015 (UTC)
